title: Can you do a bank levy and a wage garnishment at the same time?
question: i won a judgement for money from my divorce and my ex refuses to pay. he also claims that if i try any levy's or garnishments that he'll file an exempt appeal. just so i won't get anything. He half owner of a business plus he has another job. He doesn't have a mortgage or rent payment either since he lives off his new girl, but he would lie and say he does.
question_tags: Divorce,Dividing debts in a divorce,Divorce appeals,Divorce and bankruptcy,Bankruptcy,Debt,Wage garnishment,Bankruptcy and debt,Lawsuits and disputes,Appeals,Court basics
answers: You can do both. If he files a Claim of Exemption, you can oppose it by filing with the court. All of the issues about his financial situation can be discussed in front of the judge at the hearing. I suggest that you go for it. If you do nothing, you are guaranteed to recover nothing.

I agree with my colleagues; you may do both. And as Mr. Lysle stated, if he files a claim of exemption, you may oppose it and set the matter for court hearing. The judge will then decide how much is levied/garnished.

The Rutter Group's "Enforcing Judgments and Debts" is an excellent resource for determng the procedures to collect your judgment. You can find this practice guide in your local public law library.

Of course, you can also consult with a collections attorney who practices in the county in which the judgment was entered.

Good luck.
